Type of Administration:
Independent board appointed by governor exercises pardon power, except governor has authority in capital cases.
Ala. Const. amend. 38 (amending Art. V § 124); Ala. Code §§ 15-22-20 through 15-22-40. The board must make a full annual report to the governor. § 15-22-24(b).
Type of Process: Public hearings at regular intervals; 30 days' notice must be given to the attorney general, prosecutor, sentencing judge, chief of police and the county sheriff, and the victim. Ala. Code § 15-22-23l. Each board member gives reasons for vote. Process takes about one year.
Eligibility Requirements: Following completion of sentence, incl. fine, no pending charges, or after 3 years "permanent parole" unless pardon sought for actual innocence. Ala. Code § 15-22-36(c). Federal and out-of-state offenders eligible.
Effect: Only as specified in grant (full pardons rare); predicate unless expressly provided. Ala. Code § 15-22-36.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:More than 500 pardons granted annually; 2000+ restoration of rights.
Alternative Restoration: None.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board must be consulted but advice not binding. Alaska Const. art. III, § 21; Alaska Stat. § 33.20.080.
Type of Process: No formal regulations, no public hearing. Parole board staff investigates, consults with DA and court, prepares confidential recommendation to governor. Alaska Stat. § 33.20.080.
Eligibility Requirements: Parole board staff must find a person eligible to apply on merits.
Effect: Conviction set aside, may not serve as predicate or be used by licensing board, but conduct may be taken into account.
Frequency of Grants: Rare: Only three pardons since 1995.
Alternative Restoration: Judicial set aside after deferred sentencing. Alaska Stat. § 12.55.085 et seq.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, may not act without affirmative clemency board recommendation. Ariz. Const. art. V, § 5; Ariz. Rev. Stat. § 31-402(A). Governor must publish reasons for each grant, and report regularly to legislature. Ariz. Rev. Stat. §§ 31-445, -446.
Type of Process: Board meets monthly; must publish application, hold public hearing, publish recommendation to governor with reasons. Ariz. Rev. Stat. §§ 31-401, 31-402.
Eligibility Requirements: Any Arizona felony offender. Ariz. Rev. Stat. § 31-402.
Effect: Pardon relieves legal consequences, but conviction must still be reported and is given predicate effect. 68 Ariz. Op. Att'y Gen. 17.
Frequency of Grants:
Infrequent: Pardons increasingly rare since 1990; Gov. Brewer issued only 12 pardons in her 6 years in office, all in her last year.
Governor Ducey has issued no pardons to date.
Alternative Restoration: Judicial set-aside for non-serious offenders; court restores firearms. Ariz. Rev. Stat. §§ 13-905 through 13-907.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board must be consulted but advice not binding. Ark. Const. art. VI, § 18; Ark. Code Ann. § 16-93-204(a). Governor must report to legislature on all grants with reasons. Ark. Const. art. VI, § 18.
Type of Process: No public hearing. Parole board must give 30 days' prior notice of favorable recommendation, and governor must give 30 days' public notice (including statement of reasons) to prosecutor and victim. Ark. Code Ann. §§ 5-4-607(d)(1);16-93-204(c)(1); 16-93-207(a).
Eligibility Requirements: No restrictions. Federal and out-of-state offenders are eligible to apply. Ark. Const. art. VI, § 18; Ark. Code Ann. § 16-93-204.
Effect: Relieves legal disabilities, expungement automatic in all but cases involving serious violence; must specifically restore firearms rights. May not be used as predicate or to enhance. Ark. Code Ann. §§ 16-93-301 to 16-93-303.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:About 100 grants each year, 300-500 applications annually.
Alternative Restoration:
Sealing for first offenders and probationers. Ark. Code Ann. § 16-93-1201
et seq.; § 5-4-311.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board may be consulted. For recidivists, board must be consulted, majority of supreme justices must recommend.. Cal. Const. art. V, § 8; Cal. Penal §§ 4800, 4812-4813, 4852.16. Governor report grants to legislature, including facts and reasons for grants. Cal. Const. art. V, § 8; Cal. Penal § 4852.16.
Type of Process: No provision for public hearing. Certificate of rehabilitation from court (PD representation), or direct application to board if non-resident or misdemeanant. Cal. Penal Code § 4852 et seq.
Eligibility Requirements: 10 years after completion of sentence.
Effect: Described as "an honor," restores civil rights and removes occupational bars, but no expungement; guns separately restored. May be used as predicate. Cal. Penal Code §§ 4852.15, 4853.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and regular:Very few pardons between 1990 and 2011, but Jerry Brown has granted 399 pardons through December April 2014.
Alternative Restoration: Set-aside for probationers; certificate of relief. Cal. Penal Code § 1203.4(a).

Type of Administration: Governor decides ("subject to such regulation as may be prescribed by law relative to the manner of applying"). Colo. Const. art. IV, § 7. Non-statutory advisory scheme; Governor sends legislature "a transcript of the petition, all proceedings, and the reasons for his action." Colo. Const. art. IV, § 7.
Type of Process: No hearing, governor as a matter of policy seeks views of corrections authorities, DA and judge. Colo. Rev. Stat. §§ 16-17-101; 16-17-102.
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility restrictions.
Effect: Restores civil rights and firearms privileges, assists with licensing and employment, recognizes meritorious achievement and rewards exceptional citizenship. Does not authorize sealing.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent: Pardons infrequent since 1990s, although Governor Bill Ritter issued almost 30 pardons at the end of his term.
Alternative Restoration: Drug convictions may be sealed after waiting periods from 3 to 10 yrs. Colo. Rev. Stat. § 24-72-308.6.

Type of Administration: Independent board appointed by governor exercises pardon power. Conn. Gen. Stat. § 54-124a(f).
Type of Process: Public hearings at regular intervals at which applicant must be present, with reasons for denial given. Board may dispense with hearing in certain classes of cases. Process takes about one year. Conn. Gen. Stat. § 54-124a(e)?(k).
Eligibility Requirements: 5 years following completion of sentence; misdemeanants may apply. Provisional pardon/Certificate of Relief may be sought any time after sentencing. Conn. Gen. Stat. § 54-130e(b).
Effect: Relieves all legal disabilities, results automatically in "erasure" of conviction, destruction of records after three years, after which no predicate effect. Provisional pardon relieves one or more "barriers and forfeitures." Conn. Gen. Stat. § 54-142a(d).
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:About 400 pardon grants annually, including provisional pardons (about 30% of applicants get hearing, most of those granted); more than half to misdemeanants.
Alternative Restoration: None; law prohibits discrimination in licensing and employment. Conn. Gen. Stat. § 46a-80.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, may not act without affirmative clemency board recommendation. Del. Const. art. VII, § 1. Governor must report periodically to legislature. Id.
Type of Process: Pardon board, chaired by lieutenant governor, public hearings at regular intervals, recommendations and reasons announced. Favorable recommendations sent to governor. Process takes about six months. Del. Const. art. VII; Del. Code. Ann. tit.11, § 4362.
Eligibility Requirements: 3-5 years following completion of sentence, absent hardship; misdemeanants may apply.
Effect: Relieves disabilities except constitutional prohibition against holding state office for "infamous offense." May be used as predicate and to enhance subsequent sentence. Del. Code. Ann. tit. 11, § 4364. Only pardoned misdemeanor convictions may be sealed. § 4375.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:Over 250 pardons annually in recent years, (about 85% of applications received are approved by Board and 90% of those granted by governor). Applications have tripled since 2005.
Alternative Restoration:
Expungement for deferred adjudication and diversion, pardoned misdemeanor convictions. Del. Code Ann. tit.
11, §§ 4371-4375.

Type of Administration: President decides under a non-statutory advisory scheme. U.S. Const. art II, § 2.
Type of Process: Informal process described in 28 C.F.R. Part 1 and United States Attorneys Manual. No time limit, and applications may remain pending for years.
Eligibility Requirements: 5 years after sentence or release from confinement. 28 C.F.R. Part 1.
Effect: Relieves legal disabilities and signifies rehabilitation and good character. May be used as predicate. 1995 WL 861618 (1995).
Frequency of Grants: Rare:Only a handful of DC offenders have been pardoned by the president since 1980.
Alternative Restoration: Expungement of minor D.C. Code offenses. D.C. Code § 16-801 et seq.

Type of Administration: Governor decides with concurrence of two cabinet officials. The governor and three cabinet officials act as pardon board. Fla. Const. art. IV, §8 (a); Fla. Stat. ch. 940.01, 940.05. Governor reports to legislature each restoration and pardon. Id. at 940.01.
Type of Process: Public hearing for pardon, and for restoration of rights for many offenders (offenses specified in clemency rules). Hearings are held on a quarterly basis, DA and victims notified. Separate process for firearms restoration.
Eligibility Requirements: Eligibility immediately following completion of sentence. Out-of-state and federal offenders eligible for ROR but not pardon (R. 9D).
Effect: Pardon "unconditionally releases the person from punishment and forgives guilt." Id. Restores firearms rights. Id. at 4A. May be used as predicate. ROR restores vote and other basic civil rights. (R. 4F).
Frequency of Grants: Sparing: 20-40 pardon grants annually between 2006 and 2010; 20-30 firearms restoration grants annually (about half of applications). Restorations of rights number in thousands.
Alternative Restoration: Sealing and expungement for misdemeanors and minor felonies.Fla. Stat. ch. 943.0585(1)(b)(1); 943.0585. Deferred adjudication. Fla. Stat. ch. 948.01(2).

Type of Administration: Independent board appointed by governor exercises pardon power. Ga. Const. art. IV, § 2, para. II. Board must report annually to legislature, the Attorney General and the Governor. Ga. Code Ann. § 42-9-19.
Type of Process: Paper review, no public hearing. Board decides cases by majority vote, and in a written opinion. Ga. Code Ann. §§ 42-9-42(a) and (b); 42-9-43.
Eligibility Requirements: 5 years following discharge; out-of state offenses eligible for restoration of rights but not pardon. Drug and violent offenses ineligible to apply by Board policy.
Effect: Relieves all legal disabilities except return to public office. No sealing, and may be used as predicate. Ga. Code Ann. § 42-9-54; Morris v. Hartsfield, 197 S.E. 251 (Ga. 1938).
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:Between 300-400 pardons w/o gun rights; 100 pardons w/ gun rights, several hundred "restoration of rights"(approx. 35% of applicants); immigration pardons.
Alternative Restoration: Deferred adjudication and 'exoneration' for first offenders. Ga. Code. Ann. § 42-8-60 et seq.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board may be consulted. Haw. Const., art. V, § 5; Haw. Rev. Stat. § 353-72.
Type of Process: No public hearing; parole boards interviews applicant, recommends to AG's office, which conducts independent investigation and makes recommendation to governor. Process takes 8 months. Haw. Rev. Stat. § 353-72.
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility requirements.
Effect: A pardon will state that the person has been rehabilitated, relieves legal disabilities and prohibitions. No expungement, may be used as predicate. Haw. Rev. Stat. §§ 353-62, 353-72.
Frequency of Grants: Uneven: Governor Abercrombie issued 33 pardons, fewer than his predecessors. Governor Lingle granted 132 pardons in 8 yrs., 55 in her last year (2010). About 50 applications filed per year.
Alternative Restoration: Deferred adjudication and expungement; state FEP laws includes conviction. Haw. Rev. Stat. §§ 853-1; 831-3.

Type of Administration: Independent board appointed by governor decides all but violent and drug offenses, which must be approved by governor. Idaho Const. art. IV, § 7; Idaho Code Ann. §§ 20-210, 20-240.
Type of Process: Public hearing at regular intervals; reasons for each action must be filed with Secretary of State. Idaho Code §§ 20-210, 20-240; see IDAPA § 50.01.01.
Eligibility Requirements: Three years for non-violent offenses, five years for violent. Idaho Code § 18-310(3).
Effect: Relieves certain legal disabilities, including firearms. Idaho Code § 18-310. Does not expunge.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:In recent years 20-30 grants annually, from 30-60% of applications filed.
Alternative Restoration: Deferred adjudication but no expungement; ex. for some juvenile offenses.Idaho Code § 19-2601 et seq.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, although "the manner of applying therefore may be regulated by law." Ill. Const. art. V, § 12. Prisoner Review Board authorized to provide advice to governor. 730 Ill. Comp. Stat, Ann. 5/3-3-1(a)(3).
Type of Process: Public hearings at regular intervals before the Prisoner Review Board, which makes confidential recommendations to Governor. 730 Ill. Comp. Stat. 5/3-3-1 et seq.
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility requirements.
Effect:
Relieves legal disabilities; expungement only if authorized by the grant. People v. Glisson,
358 N.E.2d 35 (Ill. App. Ct. 1976).
Frequency of Grants: Uneven, varies with administration: Between 2009 and April 2014, Gov. Quinn granted 1075 pardons, about half of those that applied. Since 2014 many fewer granted by Governor Rauner, though still regular practice. Board hears 800 applications each year.
Alternative Restoration: Judicial certificates; sealing for most convictions after three-year waiting period. 730 Ill. Comp. Stat. 5/5-5.5-5 et seq.; 20 Ill. Comp. Stat. 2630/5 et seq.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, "subject to such regulations as may be provided by law." Ind. Const. art. 5, § 17. Parole board makes advisory recommendations to governor. Ind. Const. art. 5, § 17; Ind. Code §§ 11-9-2-1 to 11-9-2-3. Governor reports to legislature. Ind. Const. art. 5, § 17.
Type of Process: Public hearing; parole board notifies victim, court, and DA; conducts investigation and holds hearing at which petitioner and other interested parties are may present their position.Ind. Code § 11-9 et. seq.
Eligibility Requirements: Recent governors have required a 5-year waiting period and evidence of rehabilitation. 15 years for firearms restoration.
Effect: Pardon wipes out both the punishment and the guilt, basis for expungement. Kelley v. State, 185 N.E. 453 (Ind. 1933). See also State v. Bergman, 558 N.E.2d 1111 (Ind. Ct. App. 1990); Ind. Code § 35-47-2-20(a); § 11-9-2-4.
Frequency of Grants: Sparing: Gov. Pence issued only three pardons. Gov. Daniels granted 62 pardons during his eight years in office, acting favorably on about half of those recommended by board.
Alternative Restoration: Expungement for most offenses; sealing for misdemeanors, Class D felonies, and nonconviction records. Ind. Code § 35-38-9; § 10-13-3-27(a).

Type of Administration: Governor decides "subject to such regulations as may be provided by law." Iowa Const. art. IV, § 16. Parole board authorized to provide advice. Iowa Code §§ 914.1-914.7. Governor reports to legislature on pardons issued and reasons. Iowa Const. art. IV, § 16.
Type of Process: Paper review, no public hearing for pardon and restoration of rights. Separate firearms restoration procedure. Iowa Code § 914 et seq.
Eligibility Requirements: 10 years for pardon, 5 years for firearms; no waiting period for restoration of rights. Out-of-state and federal eligible for ROR. Iowa Code § 914.2.
Effect: Pardon relieves all legal disabilities (incl. public employment disabilities). See Slater v. Olson, 299 N.W. 879 (Iowa 1941). Restoration of rights restores right to vote and hold public office, may also restore firearms rights. Does not seal or expunge.
Frequency of Grants: Uneven, varies with administration: Average of 35 full pardons each year between 2005 and 2011 (fewer since 2009 and in recent years increasingly rare), with another 30-60 grants to restore civil rights and firearms privileges
Alternative Restoration: Restoration of gun rights by governor; Deferred adjudication and expungement for some first offenders.Iowa Code §§ 907.3; 914.7

Type of Administration: Governor decides, subject to regulations and restrictions by law. Kan. Const. art. I, § 7. The governor required to seek the advice of the prisoner review board, though not bound to follow it, Kan. Stat. Ann. § 22-3701(4). Reports to legislature on each pardon application but need not give reasons. Kan. Stat. Ann. § 22-3703.
Type of Process: Paper review. Applicant must publish a copy of the application in a newspaper in county of conviction at least 30 days before grant or pardon is void. Applicant must also provide notice of application to DA, judge and victim. Kan. Stat. Ann. § 22-3701 et seq.
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility requirements, except that only Kansas state convictions are eligible to be pardoned or commuted. Kan. Stat. Ann. § 22-3701.
Effect: Pardon removes disabilities imposed under state law, but does not expunge conviction or lift bar to service as a law enforcement officer.Cf.Kan. Att'y Gen. Op. No. 85-165 (1985). May be used as predicate.
Frequency of Grants: Rare: Pardons very rare, primarily for miscarriage of justice
Alternative Restoration: Expungement for many felony offenses. Kan. Stat. Ann. § 21-4619 et seq.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board may be consulted. Ky. Const. § 77. Governor may also restore rights of citizenship, office. Id. §§ 145, 150. Governor reports to legislature reasons for each grant. Id. § 77.
Type of Process: No public hearing. Pardon applications sent directly to the governor with reasons for seeking relief and letters of recommendation. Simplified ROR process administered by DOC. Ky. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 439 et seq.
Eligibility Requirements: For restoration of rights, expiration of sentence with no pending charges. For pardon 7-year waiting period. Federal and out-of-state offenders eligible for restoration of rights.Arnett v. Stumbo, 153 S.W.2d 889 (1941).
Effect: Restoration of citizenship restores a person's right to vote and eligibility for jury service. A full pardon relieves additional legal disabilities. May be used as predicate. Ky. Const. § 145(1); Leonard v. Corrections Cabinet, 828 S.W.2d 668 (Ky. Ct. App. 1992)
Frequency of Grants: Uneven: Pardons during term have been rare, but current governor (Bevin) may depart from this practice, announcing 10 pardons in July 2017 and indicating there would be more. ROR to restore vote frequent.
Alternative Restoration: Misdemeanor expungement. Ky. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 431.078.

Type of Administration: "Upon favorable recommendation of the Board of Pardons," the Governor may pardon "those convicted of offenses against the state."La. Const. art. IV, § 5(E)(1); La. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 15:572(A).
Type of Process: Regular public hearings, approval by four of five board members; DA and victim notified by board, and by applicant through publication of application in newspaper. La. Const. art. IV, § 5(E)(2); La. Rev. Stat. Ann. 15:572.1.
Eligibility Requirements: Completion of sentence, plus payment of costs. La. Const. art. IV, § 5(E)(1); La. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 15:572(A); see Op. La. Att'y Gen. No. 04-0080 (2005).
Effect: Full pardon restores to "status of innocence," conviction cannot be used to enhance punishment. State v. Riser, 30,201 (La. App. 2 Cir. 12/12/97).
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent/uneven:In 4 years, Gov. Jindal issued 36 pardons and commuted one sentence, failing to act on hundreds of recommendations from the Board. Previous governors granted 331 (in 4 years) and 476 (in 8 years). Edwin Edwards granted over 3,000 in 16 years.
Alternative Restoration: Deferred adjudication and expungement. La. Const. art. IV, § 5(E)(1); La. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 15:572(B)(1).

Type of Administration: Governor decides, subject to regulation "relative to the manner of applying." Non-statutory advisory scheme. Me. Const. art. V, pt. 1, § 11.
Type of Process: Public hearings at regular intervals; board makes confidential recommendations to governor. Parole board conducts investigation. Applicant notifies DA, publishes notice of hearing in a newspaper 4 weeks beforehand. Me. Rev. Stat. Ann. tit. 34-A, § 5210(4); tit. 15, § 2161.
Eligibility Requirements: 5 years following completion of sentence.
Effect:
Relieves legal disabilities. Me. Rev. Stat. Ann.
tit. 16, §§ 611-622.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent/uneven: As of April 2013, Gov. Lepage had granted only about 30 pardons since taking office in 2011 . Between 2002 and 2011, Governor Baldacci granted 131 pardons, 51 in his final year. In past about 50 hearings each year, 25% result in pardon.
Alternative Restoration: No other relief provided

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board may be consulted. Md. Const. art. II, § 20; Md. Code Ann., Correctional Services § 7-206(3)(ii). Constitution requires governor to publish notice of intention to grant, and to report grants to legislature with reasons. Md. Const. art. II, § 20.
Type of Process: Paper review by Parole Commission, whose recommendations to the governor are not binding.Md. Code Ann. § 7-206(3)(ii).
Eligibility Requirements: Felony convictions must have 10 crime-free years to be eligible (seven if Parole Commission waiver granted); misdemeanants must have 5 crime-free years. 20-year wait for crimes of violence and drugs (or 15 if waiver granted).
Effect: Pardon lifts all disabilities and penalties imposed. Firearms privileges must be specifically restored in pardon document. Non-violent first offenders entitled to expungement.
Frequency of Grants: Sparing/Uneven: As of August 2017, Governor Hogan had granted no pardons. Governor O'Malley granted about 150 pardons in his eight years in office, Ehrlich (2003-2007) granted 228 pardons out of a total of 439 applications.
Alternative Restoration: Probation before judgment and expungement.Md. Code Ann., Crim. Proc. § 6-220(b)(1); § 10-105(a)(8).

Type of Administration: Governor may not act without affirmative recommendation of Governor's Council. Mass. Const. pt. 2, ch. II, sec. I, art. VIII. Governor must report to legislature annually with a list of pardons granted, but not required to give reasons. Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 127, § 152 (2011).
Type of Process: Petitions filed with Parole Board, which recommends to Governor and Council. Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 127, § 152 (2011). Public hearing, referral to AG, DA, court, notice to victim. 120 Mass. Code Regs. 902.02-.12 (2011). Public report to governor and Council. Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 127, § 154 (2011).
Eligibility Requirements: 15 years after conviction or release from prison for felonies, 10 years for misdemeanors.Governor's Executive Clemency Guidelines (April 22, 2003) at 2.
Effect: The governor, upon granting a pardon, orders the records of a state conviction sealed; thereafter, the records of the conviction may not be accessed by the public, and existence may be denied. Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 127, § 152 (2011).May be used as predicate.
Frequency of Grants: Rare:Pardons infrequent since early 1990s, only four since 2002 (by Governor Patrick at the end of his term).
Alternative Restoration: Sealing available for felonies after 5 years, misdemeanors after 10. Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 276, § 100A.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board must be consulted but advice not binding.Mich. Const. Art. 5, § 14; Mich. Comp. Laws §§ 791.243, 791.244. Mustinform the legislature annually of pardons and reasons. Const. Art. 5, § 14.
Type of Process: All applications referred to the board; if board decides to hold hearing, relevant officials must be notified. Recommendation of the board is a matter of public record. Mich. Comp. Laws § 791.244.
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility criteria
Effect: Pardon "releases the punishment and blots out of existence the guilt, so that in the eye of the law the offender is as innocent as if he had never committed the offense." People v. Van Heck, 651 N.W.2d 174, 179 (Mich. App. 2002).
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent/uneven: Pardons rare prior to 2006 (only 34 pardons between 1969 and 2006). Gov. Granholm granted 20 pardons, 100 commutations; Rick Snyder granted no pardons during first term, 11 at start of second.
Alternative Restoration: First offender set-aside; probation before judgment for drug offenders. Mich. Comp. Laws § 780.621l; § 333.7411.

Type of Administration: Governor and high officials (attorney general, chief justice) act as board exercising power. Minn. Const. art. V, § 7. Board required to report to legislature by February 15 each year. Minn. Stat. § 638.075.
Type of Process: Commissioner of corrections screens applications, decides which cases should be heard by board. Minn. Stat. § 638.07. Public hearing, notice to officials and victim, decision announced at conclusion of hearing.
Eligibility Requirements: For "pardon extraordinary," 5 crime-free years from final discharge for nonviolent crimes, or 10 crime-free years from final discharge for "violent" offenses (which includes drug felonies). Minn. Stat. §638.02.
Effect: A "pardon extraordinary" restores all rights, including firearms rights, and has "the effect of setting aside and nullifying the conviction," so that it need not be disclosed. Minn. Stat. § 638.02. Does not seal or expunge the record, may be used as predicate.
Frequency of Grants: Regular but sparing; 10-20 pardons each year, about one third of those whose cases are heard. Only those deemed eligible are permitted to file an application, and waivers of the eligibility waiting period are rarely granted.
Alternative Restoration: Common law and (narrow) statutory expungement. Minn. Stat. § 609A.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board may be consulted. Miss. Const. art. 5, § 124. Miss. Code Ann. § 47-7-5(3).
Type of Process: Applicants publish notice 30 days before applying, stating reasons. Miss. Const. art. 5, § 124. Facially meritorious cases sent to the parole board, which investigates and holds hearing. Board reports to Governor and legislature annually. Miss. Code Ann. § 47-7-15.
Eligibility Requirements: Seven years since completion of sentence by governor's office policy.
Effect: Pardon restores civil rights and removes employment disabilities, gun restrictions, obligation to register. No expungement.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent/uneven. No regular process. Almost 200 post-sentence pardons at end of Barbour's term considered irregular and unusual.
Alternative Restoration: First misdemeanor and a few minor felony convictions may be expunged. Miss. Code Ann. § 99-19-71.

Type of Administration: Governor grants reprieves and pardons, subject to rules and regulations prescribed for "the manner of applying." Mo. Const. art. IV, § 7. Parole board must be consulted, but advice not binding. Mo. Rev. Stat. § 217.800.2.
Type of Process: Applications referred to board for investigation and recommendation. See Mo. Rev. Stat. § 217.800.2. No provision for public hearing. Board meetings on clemency matters may be closed to public. Mo. Rev. Stat. § 217.670.5.
Eligibility Requirements: If still in jail, apply at any time. If out, eligible three years from discharge.
Effect: Pardon "obliterates" conviction, relieves of all obligations associated with the conviction (including obligation to register as sex offender). No predicate effect. No expungement.
Frequency of Grants:
Infrequent/uneven:
Governor Nixon granted 110 pardons during his eight years in office (2009-2017), but prior to that very few in recent years. Number of applications has increased dramatically, in part because of extension of firearms restrictions to long guns in 2008.
Alternative Restoration: Bad check convictions, some public order misdemeanors, andfirst-time minor alcohol offenses may be expunged. Mo. Rev. Stat. §§ 610.140, § 577.054(1). Sealing of some cases sentenced to probation. § 311.326.

Type of Administration: Governor may grant pardons and commutations, and must consult with board of pardons and paroles, but since March 2015 he may grant clemency even if board recommends denial. Mont. Const. art. VI, § 12; Mont. Code Ann. §§ 46-23-104(4), 46-23-301(3)(b). Governor must report grants to legislature including reasons. § 46-23-316.
Type of Process: Board may hold a hearing in meritorious cases where all sides are heard and a record made, but is not required to do so. Governor may ask the Board to hold a hearing if it has declined to do so. See Mont. Code. Ann. § 46-23-301(3)(b).
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility criteria.
Effect: Pardon removes "all legal consequences" of conviction, including licensing bars, and is grounds for expungement.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent: Between 2005 and present, only 25 individuals pardoned.
Alternative Restoration: Deferred adjudication and expungement. Mont. Code. Ann. § 46-18-201.

Type of Administration: Governor and high officials (secretary of state and attorney general) act as board of pardon which exercises power. Neb. Const. art. IV, § 13. Governor chairs board.
Type of Process: Public hearings held quarterly, victims notified. No reasons given. Board of Parole may advise the Board of Pardon "on the merits of any application . . . but such advice shall not be binding on them." Neb. Const. art. IV, § 13. Process takes about one year.
Eligibility Requirements: Informal rule of 10 years following completion of sentence for felonies, 3 years for misdemeanors.
Effect: Restores civil rights other than vote; gun rights must be separately restored. Neb. Rev. Stat. § 83-1,130.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:Over 100 pardons granted each year between 2002 and 2013, plus reprieves from driver's license revocations. About 70% of grantees also regained firearms privileges. 50% of applicants are granted, 1/3 misdemeanants.
Alternative Restoration: Set-aside for probationers, no sealing.

Type of Administration: Governor and high officials (justices of state supreme court, and attorney general) act as board exercising power. Nev. Const. art. 5, § 14. Governor must report to the legislature at the beginning of each session every clemency action (no reasons necessary). Nev. Const. art. 5, § 13.
Type of Process: Public hearings at regular intervals, at which applicant must attend; ex. non-violent first offenders may be considered on a paper record. County attorney, court and victim notified 30 days before hearing. Decision by majority (must include governor). One-year process. Nev. Rev. Stat. §§ 213.010, 213.020.
Eligibility Requirements: Variable, between five and twelve years from release from prison or discharge from parole. Waivable with consent of a board member. Nev. Admin. Code § 213.065.
Effect: Removes all disabilities, including gun disabilities and licensing bars, but does not "erase conviction" and licensing boards may condition licensure on finding of good moral character. May serve aspredicate. Nev. Rev. Stat. § 213.090.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:An average of 60 grants each year since 2013, more than half of those those that apply. (In 2017, 83 applied, 60 heard, 55 granted.)
Alternative Restoration: Sealing for most convictions after eligibility period of 7-15 years.

Type of Administration: Governor acts upon the advice of the Executive Council. N.H. Const. pt. 2, art. 52. Governor traditionally will not act without majority recommendation from Council.
Type of Process: Notice to state's attorney. N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 4.21. Hearing at direction of Governor. N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 4.28.
Eligibility Requirements: Persons eligible for "annulment" under N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 651:5 will generally not be considered for a pardon.
Effect: A pardon eliminates all consequences of conviction, but it does not expunge record. Doe v. State, 328 A.2d 784 (N.H. 1974).
Frequency of Grants: Rare:The Attorney General's office receives about 25 applications for clemency per year, but only two pardons and two sentence commutations since 1996.
Alternative Restoration: Annulment available for most felony convictions. N.H. Rev. Stat. Ann. § 651:5.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board may be consulted. N.J. Const. art. V, § 2, ¶ 1. Governor must report annually to the legislature the particulars of each grant, with the reasons. N.J. Stat. Ann. § 2A:167-3.1.
Type of Process: The Governor may refer applications for pardon to the Parole Board for recommendation. N.J. Stat. Ann. § 2A:167-7, but the recommendation does not bind Governor.
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility criteria.
Effect: Restores rights and make eligible for expungement. In the Matter of the Petition of L.B., 848 A.2d 899, 900 (N.J. Super. 2004).
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent:Recent governors have granted relatively few pardons, and generally only at end of their terms.
Alternative Restoration: First offender set-aside. N.J. Stat. Ann. §§ 2C: 52-1?32.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, ("[s]ubject to such regulations as may be prescribed by law"). N.M. Const. art. V, § 6. Parole board may be consulted. N.M. Stat. Ann. § 31-21-17.
Type of Process: Governor may send application to parole board for investigation. N.M. Stat. Ann. § 31-21-17. Board seeks recommendation from attorney general, judge, prosecuting attorney, and/or the corrections secretary. The victim must be notified.
Eligibility Requirements: Completion of sentence (by statute). Gov. guidelines require lengthy waiting periods depending on offense; no first degree felonies, DV or sex offenses, or multiple convictions.
Effect: Restores rights of citizenship and relieves other legal disabilities under state law, but does not expunge records, or preclude use of conviction as predicate offense and to enhance subsequent sentence.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent: Pardons granted only in "extraordinary circumstances." Relatively infrequent (Gov. Martinez has issued no pardons; Gov. Richardson issued 80 pardons in 10 years).
Alternative Restoration: Expungement for first offender drug possession; deferred adjudication but conviction remains on record. N.M. Stat. Ann § 30-31-28.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, subject to regulation in "the manner of applying for pardons." N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 4.Governor must report annually to legislature on pardons but not his reasons for granting them. Id.
Type of Process:
Board of Parole must advise the governor on clemency cases if requested. N.Y. Exec. Law § 259-c (8). Absent exceptional or compelling circumstances, a pardon will not be considered if there is an adequate administrative remedy available.


Special process for misdemeanor/non-violent felony committed at age 16 or 17. Grant is recommended if certain screening requirements are met (including 10 crime-free years), regardless of need or availability of administrative relief.
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility criteria
Effect: A pardon addresses unusual circumstances when adequate relief cannot be obtained by certificate; effect to "exempt from further punishment." May serve as predicate.
Frequency of Grants:
Uneven: As of July 1, 2017, Gov. Cuomo had granted only seven pardons, most for immigration purposes.
Also, more than 100 “conditional” pardons through the youthful offender program. Gov. Paterson granted 33 immigration pardons in 2010, and a handful of others.
Alternative Restoration: Certificates of relief from disabilities and certificates of good conduct.

Type of Administration: Governor's power unlimited, subject only to regulation in the manner of applying. N.C. Const. art. III, § 5(6). Post Release Supervision and Parole Commission has authority to assist the Governor in exercising his power. N.C. Gen. Stat. § 143B-720(a).
Type of Process: Applications must be submitted to the governor in writing, with statement of reasons. Governor's office of executive clemency (OEC) processes requests, oversees investigations by Parole Commission, and prepares reports. Victim may present a written statement. N.C. Gen. Stat. § 15A-838. DA must also be notified.
Eligibility Requirements: General waiting period of 5 years after completion of sentence, per executive policy.
Effect: 3 types of pardon: pardon of forgiveness (useful in seeking employment); pardon of innocence; and unconditional pardon ("granted primarily to restore an individual's right to own or possess a firearm").
Frequency of Grants: Rare:Pardons in recent years have been rare - only six pardons since 2001, all granted for innocence. Pardon applications average about 150 annually.
Alternative Restoration: Minor nonviolent felonies and misdemeanors eligible for expungement after 15 years, N.C. Gen Stat. § 15A-145.5.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, N.D. Const. art. V, § 7, and may appoint a "pardon advisory board," consisting of the state attorney general, two members of the parole board, and two citizens. N.D. Cent. Code § 12-55.1-02.
Type of Process: No public hearing; board meets twice a year, applications must be filed 90 days in advance; DA notified.
Eligibility Requirements: Inmates who are not eligible for parole can apply to the pardon board; as may non-incarcerated offenders or others who demonstrate "compelling need."
Effect: Relieves collateral penalties, but no expungement; may serve as predicate. N.D. Cent. Code § 12-55.1-01.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent:Between 2005 and 2009, 163 applications received but only six pardons granted.
Alternative Restoration: Deferred sentencing; reduction of minor felony offenses to misdemeanors. N.D. Cent Code § 12.1-32-07.

Type of Administration: Governor decides in consultation with parole board. Must report to legislature details of each commutation and pardon granted, and reasons for each. Ohio Const. art. III, § 11; Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2967.07.
Type of Process: Application to Parole Board, which conducts investigation. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2967.07. Prior notice to court, prosecutor, victim. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2967.12. Meritorious cases may be granted a hearing, and a recommendation made to governor.
Eligibility Requirements: Eligibility at any time.
Effect: Pardon forgives the conviction but does not entitle recipient to have court records sealed. State v. Radcliff.
Frequency of Grants: Sparing: Gov. Kasich has granted 86 pardons through 2016. Gov. Strickland granted 290 pardons in four years, mostly to minor non-violent offenses.
Alternative Restoration: First offender sealing.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, may not act without affirmative recommendation of board of pardons and parole. Okla. Const. art. VI, § 10. The governor must report to the legislature on each grant at regular session, though not required to give reasons. Id.
Type of Process: Public hearings at regular intervals, but applicant generally does not appear; favorable recommendations announced publicly and sent to governor; no reasons given. Process generally takes about six months.
Eligibility Requirements: Following completion of sentence or 5 years under supervision; misdemeanants eligible.
Effect: Relieves legal disabilities, including firearms. Okla. Stat. tit. 21, § 1283A. Grounds for expungement for non-violent first offenders 10 years after conviction. Okla. Stat. tit. 22, § 18.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:About 100 pardon grants annually (80% of those that apply).
Alternative Restoration: Judicial sealing for first offender misdemeanants after 10 years. Okla. Stat. tit. 22, § 18.

Type of Administration: Governor decides with no provision for advice. Or. Const. art. V, § 14. Governor must report to the legislature each grant of clemency, including the reasons for the grant.Or. Rev. Stat. § 144.660.
Type of Process: Applications filed with governor's office, copy to DA and correctional officials; review by governor's legal staff. By statute, governor may not act for 30 days after receipt of application. Or. Rev. Stat. § 144.650(4).
Eligibility Requirements: Generally governor will not consider misdemeanors and minor felonies, for which set-aside is available.
Effect: Relieves legal disabilities. As of 2019, seals the record of conviction.
Frequency of Grants:
Infrequent: The governor of Oregon has issued few pardons in recent years. Governor Kate Brown has granted four pardons in 3 1/2 years in office.
Between 2005 and January 2011, Gov. Kulongoski granted 20 pardons out of several hundred applications.
Alternative Restoration: Set-aside for misdemeanor and minor felonies. Or. Rev. Stat. § 137.225.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, may not act without affirmative recommendation of pardon board chaired by lieutenant governor. Pa. Const. art. IV, § 9(a).
Type of Process: Public hearings at regular intervals; notice published prior to hearing. 37 Pa. Cons. Stat. 81.233. Favorable recommendations are announced publicly and sent to governor; no reasons given. 37 Pa. Cons. Stat. § 81.301.
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility requirements.
Effect: Relieves all legal disabilities, including employment and licensing bars; provides grounds for expungement. Commonwealth v. C.S., 534 A.2d 1053 (Pa. 1987),
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:Of 500-600 applications, Board recommends about 150 favorably each year, most of which are granted; 20% to misdemeanors and summary offenses.
Alternative Restoration: Expungement for "violations"; law prohibits discrimination in employment and licensing. 18 Pa. Cons. Stat. § 9124.

Type of Administration: Governor decides. P.R. Const. art. IV, § 4. Parole Board may make non-binding recommendations.
Type of Process: Process administered by Parole Board. Corrections Department makes recommendation to the Parole Board, which in turn makes recommendation to the governor. There is no hearing and the process usually takes about one year.
Eligibility Requirements: No formal eligibility restrictions, but informal policy of recent governors has imposed a five-year waiting period following completion of sentence.
Effect: A grant of full pardon “erases forever” a conviction. 1960 P.R. Op. Sec’y Justice No. 33. The pardon document by its terms “eliminates” the conviction from police and court records.
Frequency of Grants: Rare: Frequency of pardon grants has decreased since expansion of expungement law in 2005.
Alternative Restoration: Broad expungement authority for all offenses, after waiting period of six months to 5 years. P.R. Laws Ann. tit. 34, §§ 1725a-1 et seq.

Type of Administration: Governor pardons "by and with the advice and consent of the senate." R.I. Const. art. IX, § 13.
Type of Process: No process specified.
Eligibility Requirements: No requirements.
Effect: Restores right to hold public office and lifts occupational and licensing bars.
Frequency of Grants: Rare:No pardon issued to a living person in many years.
Alternative Restoration: First offender expungement after 10 yrs for felonies, 5 for misdemeanors. R.I. Gen. Laws § 12-1.3-3.

Type of Administration: Independent board appointed by governor exercises pardon power except in capital cases (where governor retains power). S. C. Const. art. IV, § 14; S.C. Code Ann. § 24-21-920.
Type of Process: Board required to hold hearings at least four times a year, and in recent years every two months, at which it is required to allow the applicant to appear.
Eligibility Requirements: Following completion for sentence, or after 5 years under supervision, payment of restitution in full; state offenders only. S.C. Code Ann. § 24-21-950.
Effect: Erases legal effect of conviction, including obligation to register and use as predicate. S.C. Code Ann. §§ 24-21-990, 1000. Does not expunge, and conviction must be reported on applications.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:Board issues 300-400 grants per year, hearing about 80-85 cases every two months; grants 60-65% of applicants. Few misdemeanants.
Alternative Restoration: Various expungement authorities for minor offenses.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, S.D. Const. Article IV, § 3. Board of Pardons and Paroles must recommend pardon in order to obtain sealing relief. S.D. Codified Laws § 24-14-11.
Type of Process: Public hearings at regular intervals, recommendations sent to governor. Applicant must notify DA and sentencing judge, and must publish notice of application in a newspaper once a week for three weeks. Typically, six months to process a case. S.D. Codified Laws §§ 24-14-3, 4. Expedited procedure for misdemeanants implemented in 2014.
Eligibility Requirements: No eligibility period except 5-year waiting period after release for first offenders to apply for "exceptional pardon." S.D. Codified Laws § 24-14-8. Expedited process for misdemeanants requires waiting period of 5 and 10 years.
Effect: Persons released from all disabilities, including firearms if specified. Record sealed and conviction denied, unless pardon was issued by governor alone. S.D. Codified Laws § 24-14-11. No predicate effect.
Frequency of Grants: Frequent and Regular:Between 60 and 70 applications filed annually, about 60% recommended by Board to the governor, who grants most of those recommended.
Alternative Restoration: Deferred adjudication and judicial sealing for first offenders

Type of Administration:
Governor has the power to pardon. Tenn. Const. art. III, § 6. Governor advised by the parole board. Tenn. Code Ann. § 40-28-104. Must report grants and reasons to legislature "when requested."
Tenn. Code Ann. §§ 40-27-101, 107.
Type of Process: Public hearing and notice to prosecutor is required. Board must send names of those it is recommending and those it is not to legislative committees. Governor must notify AG and DA beforegrant is made public; they notify victim. Tenn. Code Ann. § 40-27-110.
Eligibility Requirements: Completion of sentence; additional period of good conduct and demonstration of rehabilitation and need.
Effect: Pardon has limited legal effect, and does not restore civil or other rights, for which one must go to court. Tenn. Code. Ann. § 40-29-105(c). May serve as grounds for expungement, and thus restoration of firearms rights. See Tenn. Code Ann. § 40-32-101(h)
Frequency of Grants: Uneven: In July 2017 Gov. Bevin issued 10 pardons, the first mid-term pardons in Tennessee in many years. In January 2011, Gov. Bredesen granted 22 pardons ("collected over his eight years in office"), 16 of which were recommended by the Board.
Alternative Restoration: Expungement of certain less serious non-violent offenses after 5 yrs. Judicial restoration of rights.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, may not act without affirmative recommendation of Board of Pardons and Paroles. Tex. Const. art. IV, § 11(b).
Type of Process: No public hearing, informal review process.
Eligibility Requirements: Upon completion of sentence, including misdemeanants. Tex. Admin. Cod. §§ 143.2, 143.10. First offender restoration to federal and foreign offenders. Tex. Admin. Code § 143.7.
Effect: Restores civil rights, and removes barriers "to some, but not all, types of employment and professional licensing." Basis for expungement. Predicate effect.
Frequency of Grants: Sparing:Eight to tenpardons annually most years since 2001, and 1/3 of those recommended. 200 applications are received annually.
Alternative Restoration: Expungement of pardoned convictions; deferred adjudication and nondisclosure.

Type of Administration: Independent board appointed by the governor. Utah Const. art. VII, § 12; Utah Code Ann. § 77-27-5(1).
Type of Process: Public hearing at regular intervals, notice to DA and victim, majority vote, with reasons given. Utah Code Ann. § 77-27-5(2).
Eligibility Requirements: Five years after expiration of sentence; offenses for which expungement not available. Utah Admin Code r. 671-315.
Effect: Restores civil rights.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent:Board receives only three to five requests for pardon a year, and only about 10 pardons have been granted in the past decade (availability of expungement makes less necessary).
Alternative Restoration: Expungement for many offenses.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board may be consulted. Vt. Const. ch. II, § 20.
Type of Process: No hearing; parole board investigates and recommends. Vt. Stat. Ann. tit. 28, § 453.
Eligibility Requirements: Generally 10 years, must show rehabilitation and employment-related need, benefit to society.
Effect: Restores rights, relieves disabilities, including firearms.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent: Governor Shumlin granted only two pardons since taking office in 2011. In his nearly 8 years in office (2003-2011), Governor Douglas granted thirteen pardons, fewer than two a year.
Alternative Restoration: Deferred adjudication and expungement.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, parole board may be consulted. Va. Const. art. V, § 12. Constitution also requires governor to make annual report to the legislature setting forth "the particulars of every case" of pardon or commutation granted, with reasons. Id.
Type of Process: No hearing, paper review by parole board. Restoration of rights applications processed in 60-days by Secretary of the Commonwealth.
Eligibility Requirements: 3-yr eligibility waiting period for restoration of rights after violent crime or serious crime; Immediate and automatic for non-violent crime, if eligible; ROR available for those convicted in Virginia, either in state or federal court. Simple pardon available after 5 years.
Effect: "Simple" pardon does not expunge the record, but helps with employment, education, and self-esteem.No expungement, has predicate effect.
Frequency of Grants: Sparing:Gov. McAuliffe pardoned 38 individuals in his first two years in office, and restored rights to thousands. Gov. McConnell restored rights generously, but pardoned only seven individuals. He also commuted two sentences retroactively to prevent deportation. Governor Kaine pardoned 108 individuals in his four years in office.
Alternative Restoration: Deferred adjudication but no expungement; judicial restoration of firearms.

Type of Administration: Governor decides. V.I. Organic Act of 1954, § 11.
Type of Process: No process specified.
Eligibility Requirements: No requirements.
Effect: Relieves bar to serving on government board or commission.
Frequency of Grants: No information available.
Alternative Restoration: Expungement available for misdemeanors, deferred adjudication, and youthful offenses.

Type of Administration: Governor decides "under such regulations and restrictions as may be prescribed by law." Wash. Const. art. III, §§ 9. Clemency board may be consulted. Wash. Rev. Code §§ 9.94A.885 (1), 10.01.120. Governor reports to legislature with reasons. Wash. Const. art. III, § 11.
Type of Process: Public hearing, DA and victims must be notified. Wash. Rev. Code § 9.94A.885 (3).
Eligibility Requirements: None
Effect: Vacates conviction, relieves all legal disabilities; conviction need not be reported, no predicate effect. Wash. Rev. Code § 994A.030 (11)(b).
Frequency of Grants: Sparing:About 35 petitions each year, 8-10 of which go to hearing. Between January 2011 and August 2017, Gov. Jay Inslee, and denied a number of favorable recommendations from Board. Gov. Gregoire (2003-2011) granted 27 pardons, two conditional, and two to avoid deportation.
Alternative Restoration: Judicial vacatur for most convictions; separate firearms restoration procedure.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, may seek advice from parole board. W. Va. Const. art. 7, § 11; W. Va. Code § 5-1-16. Governor reports facts of grants with reasons. W. Va. Const. art. 7, § 11; W. Va. Code § 5-1-16.
Type of Process: No public hearing; board must notify DA and judge 10 days before making recommendation to governor. As a matter of policy, governor always seeks recommendation from board.
Eligibility Requirements: None
Effect: Lifts most legal barriers, but does not restore firearms rights. Perito v. County of Brooke, 597 SE 2d 311, 321 (W. Va. 2004). May be given predicate effect.
Frequency of Grants: Rare:Governor receives from 50-100 applications each year, but pardon grants are rare (only 121 in 36 years, by nine governors).
Alternative Restoration: Misdemeanor first offender expungements.

Type of Administration: Governor decides under a non-statutory pardon advisory board. Wis. Const. art. V, § 6. Governor must communicate annually with legislature each case of clemency and the reasons. Wis. Const. art. V, § 6.
Type of Process: Under past governors, hearings have been held at regular intervals for those applicants that show "a demonstrated need for a pardon." No hearings held under current governor. By statute, applicants must publish notice in county paper or on courthouse door, and deliver to DA, judge and victim. Wis. Stat. §§ 304.09?.10.
Eligibility Requirements: Five-year eligibility waiting period; misdemeanants ineligible unless waiver granted.
Effect: Relieves legal disabilities and signals rehabilitation, but does not expunge or seal the conviction. May be given predicate effect.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent/uneven:Governor Walker has granted no pardons to date, and has stated an intent to accept no applications. Gov.Doyle granted 293 pardons overall, 176 in his final year, mainly for dated minor offenses, representing 15% of applicants, all with Board recommendation. Few misdemeanants.
Alternative Restoration: Expungement or sealing of certain adult misdemeanor convictions. Wis. Stat. § 973.015.

Type of Administration: Governor decides, subject to legislative controls on the manner of applying. Wyo. Const. art. 4, § 5. Governor must report every two years to legislature on grants, with the reasons for each one. Id.
Type of Process: Statutory application process involves review by governor's staff. Process takes 4-6 weeks. Notice to DA three weeks prior to acting, and DA must provide details of offense. Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 7-13-801 et seq.
Eligibility Requirements: 10 years after sentence for pardon, 5 years for restoration of rights. Excludes sex offenses.
Effect: Relieves legal disabilities but does not expunge. Maybe given predicate effect.
Frequency of Grants: Infrequent: Current governor has issued only a handful of pardons in eight years. From 2005 to 2010, 22 pardons and 28 restorations of rights (25% of applications filed).
Alternative Restoration: Governor also grants restoration of rights upon recommendation of parole board. Federal and state offenders eligible.

Type of Administration: President decides under a non-statutory advisory scheme. U.S. Const. art. II, § 2; 28 CFR Part 1. No reporting requirement, no notice.
Type of Process: Informal process described in 28 C.F.R. Part 1 and United States Attorneys Manual. No time limit, and applications may remain pending for years.
Eligibility Requirements: 5 years after sentence or release from confinement. 28 C.F.R. § 1.2. Generally not eligible if on parole. Id.
Effect: Relieves legal disabilities signifies rehabilitation. Does not expunge, has predicate effect.
Frequency of Grants: Sparing: Only about 10-15 pardons per year over the past twenty years, representing less than 5% of those who apply. President Obama has issued only 52 pardons in five years and denied more than 1300 applications with more than 800 awaiting decision.
Alternative Restoration: None
